did.abstract: Ret. Lt. Col. Alexander Jefferson, pilot and ex-P.O.W., collection of personal papers and records from the Tuskegee Airmen national organization and Detroit Chapter, and the Tuskegee Airmen National Historical Museum in Detroit, Michigan.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Alexander Jefferson (donor no. 9786) and came to the library September 2006.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Alexander Jefferson papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Ret. Lt. Col. Alexander Jefferson was born 15 November 1921 in Detroit, MI. He graduated from Clark College in Atlanta, Georgia in 1942 and was working towards a Masters Degree in chemistry from Howard University in Washington, D.C. before entering the Aviation Cadet Program at Tuskegee Army Airfield, graduating in January 1944.

Jefferson fought in World War II as a P-51 fighter pilot in the famed Tuskegee Airmen segregated air force, the "Red-Tail" 332nd Fighter Group, and flew 18 long range escort missions for B-17 and B-24 bombers. Three days before the invasion of Southern France he was shot down by ground fire while strafing radar stations over Toulon, France on 12 August, 1944 and immediately captured by German troops. Jefferson spent five months in Stalag Luft III prison before being transferred to Stalag VIIA near Mooseburg, Germany by way of marching 80 kilometers in sub-zero temperatures and pressed into a "40 and 8" boxcar. Following the war Lt. Col. Jefferson served as an instrument instructor in advance training at Tuskegee Army Air Field and as a Staff Operations and Training Officer of the 9504th Air Recovery Squadron. He was discharged from active duty in 1947 and retired from the reserves in 1969 with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel.

Alexander Jefferson earned a Masters Degree of Education from Wayne University and taught science to elementary school students in Detroit. He retired as assistant principal in 1979. Jefferson was enshrined into the Michigan Aviation Hall of Fame in 1995 and received the Purple Heart in 2004.

The first meeting of the Tuskegee Airmen took place on 14 July 1972 when a small group of veterans gathered in the home of Alexander Jefferson. Tuskegee Airmen Incorporated has since become a large national organization with 48 chapters (as of 2006), with Jefferson serving in the organization in a variety of capacities and making numerous public appearances and speeches.

scopecontent.p: The Alexander Jefferson papers are divided into five series: Personal Papers, Tuskegee Airmen Incorporated, Tuskegee Airmen Detroit Chapter, Tuskegee Airmen National Historical Museum, and Photographs.

scopecontent.p: The Personal Papers series (1.1 linear feet) contains five sub-series: Biographical materials; Correspondence; Personal items; Press; and Public Appearances.
The Biographical Materials sub-series includes several biographical summaries and a handful of manuscripts.

scopecontent.p: The Personal Items sub-series includes matters pertaining to the history of Pattengill School and Jefferson's tenure as an Air Force recruiter.

scopecontent.p: The Public Appearances sub-series demonstrates Alexander Jefferson's career as a public speaker, running the gamut from primary schools around Southeast Michigan to an International Conference in Germany. This sub-series also includes speech notes, transcripts, and a transcript of a question and answer session following a NASA-sponsored event. Some speech topics are Ret. Lt. Col. Jefferson's experiences as a pilot and prisoner of war in World War II, segregation, and the importance of education.

1994 "Be With Us, Lest We Forget," Novi, MI.

scopecontent.p: The Tuskegee Airmen Incorporated series (3.1 linear feet) comprises seven sub-series: Biographical files; Correspondence; History; Media (press, reviews, and advertisements); Organization; Press; and Public Appearances.
The Biographical Files sub-series includes information for sixty of Jefferson's fellow Tuskegee Airmen. This includes press clippings, photos, and other various ephemera.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence sub-series dates from 1974 to 2005 and again includes correspondence with Coleman Young. There are also letters pertaining to a dispute within the organization's board of directors.

The History sub-series includes some full-color books which were distributed at the National Conventions, the 487 page George L. Washington manuscript, several "one-sheets" prepared for media, and a wide variety of other documents.

scopecontent.p: The Media (press, reviews, and advertisements) sub-series relates to Tuskegee Airmen movies and books. This series also has records from a trip to Lucasfilm's Skywalker Ranch and correspondence related to this partnership.

scopecontent.p: The Organization records consist of membership lists, a record of resolutions from the 1990's, and items concerning most of the national conventions held by Tuskegee Airmen Incorporated.

scopecontent.p: The Tuskegee Airmen Detroit Chapter series (0.8 linear feet) is divided into five sub-series: Correspondence; History; Organization containing meeting minutes from 1972-2005 (excepting 1983-1988); Press, and Public Appearances, which details the organization's involvement in sponsoring a career week event during African American History Week/Month.

scopecontent.p: The Tuskegee Airmen National Historical Museum series (0.5 linear feet) contains three sub-series: Correspondence; Organization records which include invitations from the annual Salute and Reception Dinner; and Press.

did.unittitle: Management Consultant For The Arts Report 1996

scopecontent.p: The Photograph series (0.5 linear feet) is divided in the same manner as the rest of the collection with sub-series for Alexander Jefferson, Tuskegee Airmen Incorporated, Tuskegee Airmen Detroit Chapter, and Tuskegee Airmen National Historical Museum. Many of the photographs are printouts from various Internet sites or photographs of photographs. The hand-written notes may prove useful for future researchers seeking to identify individuals in already-published but unlabeled photos from the World War II era.
